items.title: Provide manylinux wheels for cuda 11
items.body: I'm currently keen to use cupy with CUDA 11.0 on Linux. Would it be possible to get manylinux wheels on pypi? It seems currently there are only Windows wheels. Thanks!

items.title: CuPy reducers return zero-dimensional arrays, rather than scalars
items.body:
One point of compatibility between CuPy and NumPy: when NumPy computes a reducer (`sum`, `prod`, `any`, `all`, `min`, `max`, ...), it returns a scalar that is interchangeable with Python numbers and inherits from `numbers.Number`:

```python
>>> np_scalar = numpy.sum(numpy.array([1, 4, 3, 0, 6]))
>>> np_scalar
14
>>> type(np_scalar)
<class 'numpy.int64'>
>>> isinstance(np_scalar, numbers.Integral)
True
>>> isinstance(np_scalar, numpy.integer)
True
>>> isinstance(np_scalar, numpy.ndarray)
False
```

but when CuPy computes a reducer, it returns a zero-dimensional array:

```python
>>> cp_scalar = cupy.sum(cupy.array([1, 4, 3, 0, 6]))
>>> cp_scalar
array(14)
>>> isinstance(cp_scalar, numbers.Integral)
False
>>> isinstance(cp_scalar, cupy.integer)
False
>>> isinstance(cp_scalar, cupy.ndarray)
True
```

The one thing they have in common is that their `shape` is an empty tuple:

```python
>>> np_scalar.shape
()
>>> cp_scalar.shape
()
```

But this is a test that can't be applied to Python numbers:

```python
>>> py_scalar = 14
>>> py_scalar.shape
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'shape'
```

The fact that this is different prevents us from being able to swap NumPy for CuPy everywhere; we need a [compatibility layer](https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward-1.0/blob/f5662b5cc3e260140064dd49960499d006f4f63f/src/awkward1/nplike.py#L248-L354) to adjust for the differences.

Is there a reason for reducers to return zero-dimensional arrays instead of scalars, or is this an accident/bug?

```
>>> cupy.show_config()
CuPy Version          : 7.7.0
CUDA Root             : /home/jpivarski/miniconda3
CUDA Build Version    : 10020
CUDA Driver Version   : 10020
CUDA Runtime Version  : 10020
cuBLAS Version        : 10201
cuFFT Version         : 10101
cuRAND Version        : 10101
cuSOLVER Version      : (10, 2, 0)
cuSPARSE Version      : 10300
NVRTC Version         : (10, 2)
cuDNN Build Version   : 7605
cuDNN Version         : 7605
NCCL Build Version    : 2406
NCCL Runtime Version  : 2708
CUB Version           : None
cuTENSOR Version      : None
```

items.title: Why some of the numpy functions are straight applicable on cupy array?
items.body:
This is simply a question instead of an issue. I've noticed, for example, `numpy.fft.fft()` can be fed with a cupy array without any issue and the computation is mounted on GPU as expected. How is this black magic implemented?

Many Thanks!

items.title: Support Visual Studio 2019 build
items.body: Building CuPy is not as simple as having "Build Tools for Visual Studio 2017" installed.  If a user has a CUDA dev environment with Visual Studio 2019, he/she has to install CUDA on top of "Build Tools for Visual Studio 2017."  It significantly increase the bar for users.

items.title: AssertionError occurs for some reductions when CUB is enabled
items.body:
I get some test suite failures in `cupyimg` when `CUPY_ACCELERATORS="cub,cutensor"` environment variable is set.

* Conditions (you can just paste the output of `python -c 'import cupy; cupy.show_config()'`)
CuPy Version          : 8.0.0b5
CUDA Root             : /usr/local/cuda-10.2
CUDA Build Version    : 10020
CUDA Driver Version   : 10020
CUDA Runtime Version  : 10020
cuBLAS Version        : 10202
cuFFT Version         : 10102
cuRAND Version        : 10102
cuSOLVER Version      : (10, 3, 0)
cuSPARSE Version      : 10301
NVRTC Version         : (10, 2)
Thrust Version        : 100907
CUB Build Version     : 100800
cuDNN Build Version   : 7605
cuDNN Version         : 7605
NCCL Build Version    : 2604
NCCL Runtime Version  : 2604
cuTENSOR Version      : 10001

* Code to reproduce

```Python
import cupy as cp
x = cp.arange(2*4*3).reshape((2, 4, 3), order='F')
x.max(-1)  # or x.max(1), but not for x.max(0) which is the contiguous axis
```

This gives the correct result, but prints:
```
AssertionError

Exception ignored in: 'cupy.cuda.cub._preprocess_array'
AssertionError
```

* Error messages, stack traces, or logs

```python
>>> import cupy as cp
>>> from cupyx.time import repeat
>>>

>>> b = cp.random.random(1000000)
>>> def my_vdot(a, b):
...     return cp.sum(a * b)
... 
>>> print(repeat(cp.vdot, (a, b)))
vdot                :    CPU:   17.272 us   +/- 0.938 (min:   16.300 / max:   39.416) us     GPU-0:  640.646 us   +/-18.809 (min:  630.496 / max:  774.144) us
```

items.title: tobytes in cupy.core.core.ndarray is missing on GPU memory
items.body:
* Conditions (you can just paste the output of `python -c 'import cupy; cupy.show_config()'`)
  - CuPy 6.0.0 (via miniconda)
  - Python 3.7.7
  - Windows 10 r2004 64 bits
  - CUDA version 10.0.130,  (cupy show config says: build 10000, Driver 11000, Runtime 10000)
  - no cuDNN, no NCCL
* Code to reproduce
```
import cupy

# Create an array in GPU memory and copy it to CPU memory and convert it to bytes
nd_array = cupy.random.randint(0,256,32,'<u1').get()

### This works
print(nd_array.tobytes())

# Create an array in GPU memory and try to convert it to bytes
nd_new_array = cupy.ndarray(32, 'uint8')
nd_new_array.set(nd_array)

### This fails
print(nd_new_array.tobytes())
```

```
b',\xec\x06R\x83\xddI\xb2os\xb9\xc2p\xa1\x1c\xc6o$\xc8\xd0\xe5\x16\xf8Fp,,oo\x96V\x1a'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tobytes_test.py", line 8, in <module>
    print(nd_new_array.tobytes())
AttributeError: 'cupy.core.core.ndarray' object has no attribute 'tobytes'
```

While checking the versions I realized that conda in windows has cupy version 6.0 but I couldn't find any version higher than that. This may be fixed in a newer version of cupy, the provided code should make it easy to test if it works in a more recent version.

items.title: FFT output dtype mismatches with NumPy's

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
This relates to the test failures we saw in #3587.

Reproducer:
```python
import numpy as np
import cupy as cp


dtypes = [np.int8, np.int16, np.int32, np.int64,
          np.uint8, np.uint16, np.uint32, np.uint64,
          np.float16, np.float32, np.float64,
          np.complex64, np.complex128]

for dtype in dtypes:
    a_np = np.random.random(100).astype(dtype)
    a_cp = cp.asarray(a_np)
    b_np = np.fft.fft(a_np)
    b_cp = cp.fft.fft(a_cp)
    if b_np.dtype != b_cp.dtype:
        print(f"in_dtype {a_np.dtype}: NumPy out_dtype {b_np.dtype}; CuPy out_dtype {b_cp.dtype}")
```
Output:
```bash
in_dtype float16: NumPy out_dtype complex128; CuPy out_dtype complex64
in_dtype float32: NumPy out_dtype complex128; CuPy out_dtype complex64
in_dtype complex64: NumPy out_dtype complex128; CuPy out_dtype complex64
```
I think CuPy is actually making sense and I don't understand:
1. why pocketfft chose to promote the dtype
2. why our tests did not discover this

We'll also need to discuss if we want to enforce a strict compliance for this issue, as our current implementation clearly has performance advantage...

cc: @emcastillo @grlee77 @peterbell10

items.title: Array masking is surprisingly memory-inefficient
items.body:
Masking any type of array with a boolean array seems to use more memory than necessary.
On my system with 11156 MiB of VRAM according to `nvidia-smi`, entering the following in an interactive console:
```
a = cupy.random.random(int(50e7))
b = a > 0.5
```
leads to the following output:
```
>>> a.nbytes/1024**2
3814.697265625
>>> b.nbytes/1024**2
476.837158203125
```

```
cupy.cuda.memory.OutOfMemoryError: Out of memory allocating 2,000,000,000 bytes (allocated so far: 10,100,000,256 bytes).
```
Even if the entire array `a` is copied during the masking operation, that should only occupy <73% of total RAM, i.e. there should still be a comfortable 3 GiB left over. Is this expected behavior? If so, is there a way to circumvent this? Unfortunately, I wasn't able to follow the chain of calls in the error message to check the source and see where the requested memory allocation came from.


output of `python -c 'import cupy; cupy.show_config()'`:

items.body:
In #3461 the new env var `CUPY_ACCELERATORS` is documented. However, the purpose and usage of reduction accelerators should also be documented. Perhaps we can just update this description to make the distinction between routine and reduction accelerators?
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/50bac854269742c5eed277208e7310ea38167a80/docs/source/reference/routines.rst#L33-L41

items.title: `cupy.array` raises `TypeError` for list of arrays of different dtypes

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
`numpy.array` seems to be called unexpectedly in `cupy.array` for such inputs.
```py
>>> cupy.array([cupy.zeros((2, 3), dtype='f'), cupy.zeros((2, 3), dtype='d')])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
    return core.array(obj, dtype, copy, order, subok, ndmin)
  File "cupy/core/core.pyx", line 1986, in cupy.core.core.array
    cpdef ndarray array(obj, dtype=None, bint copy=True, order='K',
  File "cupy/core/core.pyx", line 2065, in cupy.core.core.array
    return _send_object_to_gpu(obj, dtype, order, ndmin)
  File "cupy/core/core.pyx", line 2132, in cupy.core.core._send_object_to_gpu
    a_cpu = numpy.array(obj, dtype=dtype, copy=False, order=order,
  File "cupy/core/core.pyx", line 1171, in cupy.core.core.ndarray.__array__
    raise TypeError(
TypeError: Implicit conversion to a NumPy array is not allowed. Please use `.get()` to construct a NumPy array explicitly.
```

items.title: Cub module fails to build on v8.0.0b4 with Cuda 11.0
items.body:
When attempting to build Cupy from source at work on the latest Cuda 11.0 (with the 450.51.05 driver), the build fails when trying to build the cub module. I use Cupy for scientific computing (numerical optics) so I do not use cuTensor of cuDNN.
I followed the exact same installation procedure that worked on my personnal PC (installing the latest Cuda 11.0 with the new driver in headless mode), then try to install Cupy by first compiling using "python setup.py build" in the source directory. This fails outputing the following error :
```
/usr/local/cuda-11.0/bin/nvcc -D_FORCE_INLINES=1 -DCUPY_CUB_VERSION_CODE=100909 -I/usr/local/cuda-11.0/include/cub -I/home/tangui/Downloads/cupy/install/../cupy/core/include -I/usr/local/cuda-11.0/include -I/home/tangui/anaconda3/include/python3.7m -c cupy/cuda/cupy_cub.cu -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.7/cupy/cuda/cupy_cub.o --generate-code=arch=compute_30,code=compute_30 --generate-code=arch=compute_50,code=compute_50 --generate-code=arch=compute_60,code=sm_60 --generate-code=arch=compute_61,code=sm_61 --generate-code=arch=compute_70,code=sm_70 --generate-code=arch=compute_75,code=sm_75 --generate-code=arch=compute_80,code=sm_80 --generate-code=arch=compute_80,code=compute_80 -O2 --compiler-options="-fPIC" --std=c++11 
nvcc fatal   : Unsupported gpu architecture 'compute_30'
```
It seems that nvcc tries to compile with all possible architectures, and that the option `-generate-code=arch=compute_30,code=compute_30`  is not compatible with the latest version of nvcc that I have with the Cuda toolkit.
I looked for ways to change the nvcc compiler options to try and avoid this, but I could not find how. It seems like nvcc tries by default to compile for all architecture, but I only need sm_75 !
Thank you in advance.

-Cupy version : v8.0.0b4

items.title: cupy.percentile only calculates integer percentiles when the input data is an integer.

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
This seems to be caused by a cast of the percentiles array `q` to the same type as the input array `a` in the cupy.percentile source :

https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/adfcc44bc9a17886a340cd85b7c9ebadd94b38a1/cupy/statistics/order.py#L189

Example code to reproduce the issue:

`cupy.percentile(cupy.arange(1001).astype(cupy.int16),[98, 99, 99.9, 100]).get()`
`array([ 980.,  990.,  990., 1000.])`

`cupy.percentile(cupy.arange(1001).astype(cupy.float16),[98, 99, 99.9, 100]).get()`
`array([ 980.,  990.,  999., 1000.])`

For comparison the numpy version always calculates correctly:

`numpy.percentile(numpy.arange(1001).astype(numpy.int16),[98, 99, 99.9, 100])`
`array([ 980.,  990.,  999., 1000.])`

Cupy configuration:
CuPy Version          : 7.6.0
CUDA Root             : C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.2
CUDA Build Version    : 10020
CUDA Driver Version   : 10020
CUDA Runtime Version  : 10020

items.title: NVIDIA NCCL: 100% busy blocking.
items.body:
I have a 4-GPU setup and recently try utilizing NVIDIA NCCL library to speed up inter-GPU communication. In the test program, 4 processes were created via Python multiprocessing module and each of them was assigned one GPU. I've managed to make nccl.allGather() function working. The communication speedup was definitely noticeable even without using timeit() to check.

When I intentionally let one process skip the allGather() step, the other 3 were blocked as expected, waiting for their allGather() function to return. The issue here is that nvidia-smi shown all those 3 GPUs were fully (i.e. 100%) occupied, although the temperature remained low. There are 3 assumptions I can come up with:

1. Such busy-looping behavior is shipped with NCCL library.
2. CuPy wrapper's problem?
3. nvidia-smi is not accurate.

CuPy version: 7.6.0
CUDA version: 10.2
NCCL version: 2506

items.title: `cupy.fft.irfft` is slow
items.body:
`cupy.fft.irfft` is extremely slow and causes unexpected device synchronization.
```
fft     :    CPU:  511.504 us   +/-182.837 (min:  466.546 / max: 6098.848) us     GPU-0:  914.825 us   +/-181.750 (min:  868.352 / max: 6491.872) us
ifft    :    CPU:  516.756 us   +/-89.689 (min:  499.988 / max: 3025.299) us     GPU-0:  993.364 us   +/-83.566 (min:  970.336 / max: 3351.712) us
rfft    :    CPU:  473.139 us   +/-12.516 (min:  462.383 / max:  624.113) us     GPU-0:  711.520 us   +/-12.456 (min:  699.104 / max:  857.184) us
irfft   :    CPU:483281.932 us   +/-5010.430 (min:479695.227 / max:490367.569) us     GPU-0:483321.136 us   +/-5021.194 (min:479726.959 / max:490421.997) us
```

Reproducer:
```py
import cupy
import cupyx


a = cupy.random.rand(5000000).astype('f')

funcs = [
    cupy.fft.fft,
    cupy.fft.ifft,
    cupy.fft.rfft,
    cupy.fft.irfft,
]

for f in funcs:
    perf = cupyx.time.repeat(f, (a,), n_warmup=5, max_duration=1)
    print(perf)
```

items.title: Difference from SciPy about sparse min/max `sum_duplicates` parameter

labels.name: cat:enhancement
labels.description: Implementation that does not break interfaces.

items.body:
I'm not sure its background, but currently, sparse min/max have `sum_duplicates` parameter and its default value is `False`. However, their SciPy counterparts don't have the parameter and always sum duplicate entries as `sum_duplicates=True`.

It would be better to change its default value to `False`.

items.title: timing kernels with cupyx.time.repeat requires specifying a name

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
I have a question about convenience when using `cupyx.time.repeat` with kernels such as a `ReductionKernel` or `ElementwiseKernel`. Unless the user specifies something like `name=kernel.name` as an argument to `repeat`, it will fail when trying to access a non-existant `__name__` attribute.

Having to specify the name manually is a little inconvenient. What do you think about any of the following solutions?:

1.) try falling back to a `.name` attribute
2.) fall back to a default name (e.g.  `name=''"` or `name="unknown"`)
3.) add a `__name__` attribute to `_AbstractReductionKernel`, `ElementwiseKernel`, etc. 


minimal example:

```Python
import cupy
from cupyx.time import repeat

x = cupy.arange(8)
e = cupy.core.ElementwiseKernel('X x', 'Y y', '2 * x', 'doubler')
repeat(e, (x,))
```

```Python
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-11-2afc789db431>", line 6, in <module>
    repeat(e, (x,))

  File "/home/lee8rx/my_git/pyir/cupy/cupyx/time.py", line 53, in repeat
    name = func.__name__

AttributeError: 'cupy.core._kernel.ElementwiseKernel' object has no attribute '__name__'
```

items.title: `cupy.convolve` is slow compared to `cupyx.scipy.ndimage.convolve1d`
items.body:
* Conditions:
```
CuPy Version          : 8.0.0b4
CUDA Root             : /usr/local/cuda
CUDA Build Version    : 10020
CUDA Driver Version   : 10020
CUDA Runtime Version  : 10020
cuBLAS Version        : 10202
cuFFT Version         : 10102
cuRAND Version        : 10102
cuSOLVER Version      : (10, 3, 0)
cuSPARSE Version      : 10301
NVRTC Version         : (10, 2)
Thrust Version        : 100907
cuDNN Build Version   : 7605
cuDNN Version         : 7605
NCCL Build Version    : 2604
NCCL Runtime Version  : 2604
CUB Version           : None
cuTENSOR Version      : 10001
```

* Code to reproduce:

```python
for a_len in [1000, 10000, 100000]:
    for v_len in [10, 25, 100, 1000]:
        print(a_len, v_len)
        a = cupy.random.rand(a_len)
        v = cupy.random.rand(v_len)
        %timeit cupy.convolve(a, v, 'same'); cupy.cuda.Stream.null.synchronize()
        %timeit cupyx.scipy.ndimage.convolve1d(a, v, mode='constant'); cupy.cuda.Stream.null.synchronize()
```

* Generates the timings: (a few extra were added)

| `a_len` | `v_len` | `cupy.convolve` | `ndimage.convolve` |
| - | - | - | - |
| 1000 | 10 | 3.7 ms | 43 µs |
| 1000 | 25 | 878 µs | 45 µs |
| 1000 | 100 | 3.8 ms | 56 µs |
| 1000 | 1000 | 3.8 ms | 171 µs |
| 10000 | 10 | 1.9 ms | 43 µs |
| 10000 | 25 | 1.8 ms | 46 µs |
| 10000 | 100 | 1.9 ms | 57 µs |
| 10000 | 1000 | 2 ms | 173 µs |
| 10000 | 10000 | 2.7 ms | 1.4 ms |
| 100000 | 10 | 4.7 ms | 53 µs |
| 100000 | 25 | 5.1 ms | 57 µs |
| 100000 | 100 | 4.7 ms | 73 µs |
| 100000 | 1000 | 4.7 ms | 234 µs |
| 100000 | 10000 | 4.4 ms | 1.8 ms |
| 100000 | 100000 | 6 ms | 17 ms |

Except for the last entries, `cupyx.scipy.ndimage.convolve` is 1 to 2 orders of magnitude faster (with a few that are only twice as fast) than `cupy.convolve`. The last one however is actually much faster with `cupy.convolve`.

So it seems that except for some very large inputs and kernels, `cupy.convolve` is very slow. I think that transition could be taken care of with `cupyx.scipy.signal.choose_conv_method` and thus using `'fft'` be used for the large inputs.

Note that this does not test the other modes of `cupy.convolve`. The `'valid'` mode should also be faster with ndimage since it could be implemented by slicing the output. The `'full'` mode will be closer in times and is the main drawback of the ndimage version since it would require padding the image ahead of time (incurring a large duplication of data). However, some adjustments to the algorithm could be made to be able to pad while computing and that would then accommodate that issue.

labels.name: blocking
labels.description: Issue/pull-request is mandatory for the upcoming release.

labels.name: cat:document
labels.description: Documentation such as function documentations, comments and tutorials.

items.body:
As per the [development policy](https://github.com/cupy/cupy/wiki/Development-policies):

> Stable releases of CuPy will not follow API changes in the upstream projects, except for fixes needed to address bugs.

CuPy stable releases will follow the spec of the specific NumPy/SciPy release series (maybe the latest stable version of NumPy/SciPy at the time of CuPy RC release).
It is better to show "baseline" version of upstream projects in the docs. 
For v8, this will be NumPy 1.19.x and SciPy 1.5.x.

items.title: Sparse min/max have less SciPy-compatibility

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
The outptus of sparse min/max are less compatible to those of Scipy.

```Python
import numpy
import scipy

import cupy
from cupy import testing
import cupyx.scipy

def _make(xp, sp):
    m = testing.shaped_random((10, 20), xp=xp, dtype='f', scale=1)
    m[m < 0.95] = 0
    return sp.sparse.csr_matrix(m)

for (xp, sp) in [(numpy, scipy), (cupy, cupyx.scipy)]:
    m = _make(xp, sp).min(axis=0)
    print(m.dtype, m.shape, type(m))
```

**Output**
```Python
float32 (1, 20) <class 'scipy.sparse.coo.coo_matrix'>
float64 (20,) <class 'cupy.core.core.ndarray'>
```

items.title: empty_like should match device?
items.body:
I observed some unexpected behavior regarding `empty_like` and other `_like` functions. Specifically, the allocated arrays do not match the device of the template array; they are allocated on the default device instead. Since these function are supposed to return an array "like" the template array, shouldn't the new array have the same device as the template array?

```python
import cupy as cp

with cp.cuda.Device(1):
        a = cp.random.rand(10)
print(a.device, 'should be 1')

# Allowed without context because only one host.
ah = cp.asnumpy(a)

# Should be 1 because arrays like 'a' are on device 1.
a_like = cp.empty_like(a)
print(a_like.device, 'should be 1')

# Should be 0 because default device is zero.
c = cp.asarray(ah)
print(c.device, 'should be 0')

```
```
<CUDA Device 1> should be 1
<CUDA Device 0> should be 1
<CUDA Device 0> should be 0
```

Conditions
  - CuPy 7.5.0
  - RHEL x64
  - CUDA 10.2

items.title: Reorganize CUB environment variables

labels.name: cat:enhancement
labels.description: Implementation that does not break interfaces.

labels.name: no-compat
labels.description: Change that disrupts backward compatibility.

items.body:
Currently there're 4 CUB-related environment variables.


* CUB_PATH: used at build time to build cupy.cuda.cub
* CUPY_CUB_PATH: used at runtime to build  reduction kernel (#3244)
* CUPY_CUB_BLOCK_REDUCTION_DISABLED (default: 1): Set to 0 to enable performance boost in reduction kernel (#3244)
* CUB_DISABLED (default: 1): Set to 0 to enable CUB in various computations

We think it is better to disable CUB by default, even in CUDA 11, as users expect reproducibility (deterministic behavior). Instead, we need to provide a simple "opt-in" method to enable CUB for users needing a performance boost.

This issue proposes the followings:
* Remove CUB_PATH and CUPY_CUB_PATH (always use bundled CUB #2584 or CUDA 11 built-CUB, as user-provided CUB headers are unlikely to be used (considering we haven't requested to implement CUPY_THRUST_PATH).
  * In CUDA 11, use CUB included in CUDA runtime. If CUB headers are unavailable in system (e.g., maybe in "runtime" docker container; need to check after CUDA 11 is finally released), use CUB bundled in CuPy.
  * In CUDA 10 or earlier, always use CUB bundled in CuPy.
* Merge `CUPY_CUB_BLOCK_REDUCTION_DISABLED` and `CUB_DISABLED` into one environment variable `CUPY_BACKENDS="cub,cutensor"` (default: "", i.e., cub/cutensor disabled by default). Users can specify backends in the referred order, separated by a comma. Boolean flags (`cupy.core.cub_block_reduction_enabled` and `cupy.cuda.cub_enabled`) are removed for consistency.
* For testing and debugging purposes, provide the following undocumented APIs:
```
cupy.core.set_routine_backends(['cub', 'cutensor'])
cupy.core.set_reduction_backends(['cub', 'cutensor'])
```

(edit 2020-06-25: updated based on the latest discussion)

cc/ @leofang @anaruse

items.title: Copy Memory-mapped file into CuPy array
items.body:
Would it be possible to copy the output of `mmap.mmap` into a CuPy array of type void?
I want to read in a binary file into the GPU.

What I can do now:
1. I can use the examples [here](https://github.com/rapidsai/cusignal/issues/117) and then use `cp.asarray`.

That's not optimal, so I'l like to read the binary straight into GPU memory.
2. I'm able to do this with C++ [here](https://github.com/rapidsai/cusignal/pull/122). But will require Cython binding and memory management handling for the rest of our CuPy functions.

Would it possible to implement something like #2 with CuPy.

Example 1. Copy data from file to `mm` as raw data. Then copy to CuPy array and cast?
```python
with open(filename, "r+") as f:
    mm = mmap.mmap(
        f.fileno(),
        num_bytes,
        flags=mmap.MAP_PRIVATE,
        prot=mmap.PROT_READ,
    )

d_binary = cp.asarray(mm, dtype=cp.complex64)
```

Example 2. Copy data from file to `mm` as raw data. Then copy binary data to CuPy array? 
Once on the GPU, I can launch a kernel to reinterpret the data.
```python
with open(filename, "r+") as f:
    mm = mmap.mmap(
        f.fileno(),
        num_bytes,
        flags=mmap.MAP_PRIVATE,
        prot=mmap.PROT_READ,
    )

d_binary = cp.asarray(mm)
```

items.title: Move CUDA Low Level API to other namespace

labels.name: cat:enhancement
labels.description: Implementation that does not break interfaces.

items.body:
The `cupy.cuda` namespace is confusing.

1. `cupy.cuda` is not in NumPy
2.  Mixing Low Level API and CuPy original wrapper

Especially solving the second problem simplifies CuPy development.
(The first problem is a bit difficult because it requires design discussion.)

The implementation of some features on CuPy does not provide CUDA's Low Level API. Therefore, I think it is better to start with partial separation first.

With this change, CuPy may be able to provide Cython CUDA API in the future #130.

items.title: [FEA] Add pass-through default keywords to histogram for Dask compatibility
items.body:
NumPy [histogram](https://numpy.org/doc/1.18/reference/generated/numpy.histogram.html#numpy.histogram) has several keyword arguments that affect the output that are not supported in CuPy today.

For compatibility with Dask, it would be nice to add these keyword arguments but require that they are their default values (raising a NotImplementedError as appropriate). This would ensure that users do not get unexpected results, but likely allow `dask.array.histogram` to work on CuPy backed arrays. We do this in cuDF sometimes for Dask compatibility, such as [here](https://github.com/rapidsai/cudf/blob/a2684586fa073f76cd38d3957c323d5bbee634ca/python/cudf/cudf/core/series.py#L2259-L2262).

As an example:

```python
import cupy as cp
import numpy as np
import dask.array as da
​
arr = np.random.randint(5,10,(10,10))
darr = da.from_array(arr)
h, bins = da.histogram(darr, bins=[5,6])
h.compute()
array([36])
```

items.title: Runtime context is not ensured on a per-device basis
items.body:
Reproducer: running the whole test suite passed
```bash
pytest tests/cupy_tests/core_tests/test_raw.py
```
But running a particular test did not:
```bash
pytest tests/cupy_tests/core_tests/test_raw.py -k test_context_switch_RawModule1  # or test_context_switch_RawModule3
```
The reason is that the function `runtime._ensure_context()` is not done on a per-device basis, and in these tests in which some driver calls followed immediately after switching the device, the function mistakenly thought that the context was fully established on the new device, but it was not (only initialized, but not fully established). 

The pytest error is a bit obscure if running in the above way. Running the test code outside the test framework shows `cupy.cuda.driver.CUDADriverError: CUDA_ERROR_CONTEXT_IS_DESTROYED: context is destroyed`. 

<details><summary>This patch fixes it:</summary>

```diff
diff --git a/cupy/cuda/runtime.pyx b/cupy/cuda/runtime.pyx
index 7d0dd5a8f..351543670 100644
--- a/cupy/cuda/runtime.pyx
+++ b/cupy/cuda/runtime.pyx
@@ -35,10 +35,11 @@ cdef object _thread_local = threading.local()
 
 cdef class _ThreadLocal:
 
-    cdef bint context_initialized
+    cdef list context_initialized
 
     def __init__(self):
-        self.context_initialized = False
+        cdef int i
+        self.context_initialized = [False for i in range(getDeviceCount())]
 
     @staticmethod
     cdef _ThreadLocal get():
@@ -642,10 +643,11 @@ cdef _ensure_context():
     See discussion on https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/72 for details.
     """
     tls = _ThreadLocal.get()
-    if not tls.context_initialized:
+    cdef int dev = getDevice()
+    if not tls.context_initialized[dev]:
         # Call Runtime API to establish context on this host thread.
         memGetInfo()
-        tls.context_initialized = True
+        tls.context_initialized[dev] = True
 
 
 ##############################################################################
```

</details>

~~Will make a PR shortly.~~  **UPDATE:** See #3321.

items.title: feature request:  add ability to pass multiple arches using CUPY_NVCC_GENERATE_CODE
items.body:
It would be very helpful to change this line
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/2804af926cead8d2e80665283473a71212e824b0/cupy_setup_build.py#L765
to use list comprehension in order to pass multiple architectures on the command line.  This is useful for building the list of not included architectures from Jetson such as 53,62,and 72.

Something like this with + sign delimited works great
`return ['--generate-code={}'.format(val) for val in envcfg.split('+')]`

and allows me to build with CUPY_NVCC_GENERATE_CODE="arch=compute_62,code=sm_62+arch=compute_72,code=sm_72" and everything builds great.

labels.name: cat:test

items.body:
An error is instantiated to reraise the error here.
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/818008578179a8f8299175691634f497dccb2721/cupy/testing/parameterized.py#L92
However, `cupy.cuda.driver.CUDADriverError` does not support an interface of this format.

items.title: Drop cuDNN support in v8

labels.name: cat:enhancement
labels.description: Implementation that does not break interfaces.

items.body:
CuPy has been providing support for cuDNN since the initial release. It has been developed mainly for Chainer. However, as the last major version series of Chainer (v7.x) does not support CuPy v8+, there is no explicit use-case for cuDNN module in CuPy.

By dropping support for cuDNN, we can:

* Reduce maintenance cost to keep up with the latest cuDNN.
* Reduce wheel package footprint (200MB+) -- Reduced download time for users. As for the maintainer, the preparation of wheels for each release will also become easier.

This is still under discussion and not finalized decision. If you have any concerns please leave a comment in this issue.

```
cuFFT Version         : 10101
cuRAND Version        : 10101
cuSOLVER Version      : (10, 2, 0)
cuSPARSE Version      : 10300
NVRTC Version         : (10, 1)
cuDNN Build Version   : 7500
cuDNN Version         : 7500
NCCL Build Version    : None
NCCL Runtime Version  : None
```
I noticed a small difference between raising arrays to a power (in particular to power of 2) between cupy and numpy. I used three different methods, the ** operator, the cupy.power function and element wise product of array with itself. 
```
x=np.random.random(1000)
xcu=cupy.array(x)
xsqnp=np.power(x,2)
xsqcu1=xcu**2
xsqcu2=cupy.power(xcu,2)
xsqcu3=xcu*xcu
print(np.sum(xsqnp!=cupy.asnumpy(xsqcu1)))
print(np.sum(xsqnp!=cupy.asnumpy(xsqcu2)))
print(np.sum(xsqnp!=cupy.asnumpy(xsqcu3)))
```

The output was 209, 209, 1 for a single run, but in general, the first two methods created equal results in the range 150-300 while the third method created a result under 10.

items.title: cufftPlanMany() argument support in cupyx.scipy.fftpack.get_fft_plan
items.body:
I'm looking for the ability to do multiple overlapped FFTs on a 1D array of data. With cufftPlanMany() function in cuFFT I can set the istride/ostride and idist/odist arguments to accomplish this. I can also set the type to R2C, C2R, C2C (and other datatype equivalents).

I appreciate that cupyx.scipy.fftpack.get_fft_plan gives me the ability to set a plan prior to running multiple FFTs. However, it doesn't seem to give the same functionality as cufftPlanMany does. It is also currently restricted to C2C or Z2Z. Can get_fft_plan be expanded to give the user the same options as cufftPlanMany offers?

items.title: Possible to get / set gridDim and blockDim for custom Elementwise kernel?

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
Thanks for the great library, it's really a pleasure to work with!

I've written a custom Elementwise kernel that needs workspace memory for each thread. I'd like to allocate this beforehand and pass it through as `raw` parameters, as I often exceed the in-kernel dynamic memory limitations. To do so, I need to know how many threads are going to be launched.

From what I can tell, there is currently no way to set the grid dimensions or the block dimensions for an Elementwise kernel. There was a merge to allow Elementwise set the block_size (https://github.com/cupy/cupy/pull/2914), which seemed fine, but when I double-checked in master (https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/master/cupy/core/_kernel.pyx#L701) the max_block_size still appears to be set at the constant of 128.

At the moment, I have worked out the maximum number of threads that are going to be launched by tracing the cupy code and am using the following:
```
# line 701 in cupy/core/_kernel.pyx
block_max_size = 128 
# line 183 in cupy/cuda/function.pyx
gridx = min(0x7fffffff, (size + block_max_size - 1) // block_max_size) 
thread_count = gridx * block_max_size
```

Obviously this is not great. Is there any way to get / set the number of threads? Have I totally missed something? Thanks!

items.body: Does CuPy support PyPy? Are there any changes users need to make to ensure a build works with PyPy? If this isn't supported, is there a sense of how much work would be required here?

items.title: Convert CUDA Vectors or Device ptr to cupy arrays?
items.body:
Right now, if we have any source code base in CUDA, in order to expose the array to cupy, we bind it with pybind11 and later pass the array to cp.array.

However, this has a major drawback of moving data to and fro CPU.
Is it possible to read cupy array from GPU data pointers?
We could have a `cupy.h` that can be included that supports this, similar to `numpy.h` provided by pybind11

items.title: I tried to install using pip but it failed. So I used conda and it worked. There seems to be something wrong with the pip installation.

NCCL Runtime Version  : 2507

![numba_vs_cupy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50021634/76656967-2705db00-6547-11ea-93ec-348f3b1952be.png)

I have kernels, one Numba and one CuPy raw kernel. They are nearly identical and the CuPy raw kernel is 2x faster. But the overhead of launching _cuModuleLoadData_ and _cuModuleUnload_ make the overall execution of the CuPy function 2x **slower** than Numba. I've attached a screenshot from Nsight Systems. 

Also, code can be found https://github.com/rapidsai/cusignal/pull/31

items.title: Expected behavior when pass float64 to a CuPy raw kernel with float * input.
items.body:
CuPy Version          : 7.2.0
CUDA Root             : /usr/local/cuda
CUDA Build Version    : 10020
CUDA Driver Version   : 10020
CUDA Runtime Version  : 10020
cuBLAS Version        : 10202
cuFFT Version         : 10102
cuRAND Version        : 10102

cuSPARSE Version      : 10301
NVRTC Version         : (10, 2)
cuDNN Build Version   : 7605
cuDNN Version         : 7605
NCCL Build Version    : 2406
NCCL Runtime Version  : 2507

What is the expected behaviour when passing a cp.array(x, dtype=cp.float64) to a float * variable in a CuPy raw kernel? Also, for the opposite cp.array(x, dtype=cp.float32) to a double *.

I expected promotion and demotion like I would see in C++, but that's not the case. I'm getting all zeros.

The only combinations that work are 
cp.array(x, dtype=cp.float32) to a float *
cp.array(x, dtype=cp.float64) to a double *

items.title: Allow C++ Templating Functionality
items.body:
Would it be possible to allow C++ Templating functionality to raw kernels?

Rationale:
Instead of having multiple functions based on input type, there would be one templated global function.
